docs.snippet: FOCACCIA, a type of Italian flat bread that was virtually unknown in this country five years ago, has taken America by storm. Italian restaurants offer it in the breadbasket and some bakeries prepare it with assorted toppings. Stale focaccia, slic...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOCACCIA, a type of Italian flat bread that was virtually unknown in this country five years ago, has taken America by storm. Italian restaurants offer it in the breadbasket and some bakeries prepare it with assorted toppings. Stale focaccia, sliced and toasted, becomes Genoa toast, a type of Italian melba toast. Few breads are simpler to make. Focaccia essentially involves preparing a type of pizza dough, rolling it out, topping it with some seasonings and serving it warm or reheated.

headline.main: Focaccia, The Latest Addition to the Breadbasket

docs.snippet: LEAD: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that when the legs are done, the breast is often dry. If the breast is pink, the legs are red.

headline.main: If Only Ducks Were Sold in Parts

docs.snippet: LEAD: THE salad options are more varied than ever. Not long ago, all one could expect to find in the salad-greens department of a produce stand or supermarket was iceberg, Romaine and perhaps Boston lettuce. Today there are at least a dozen choice...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE salad options are more varied than ever. Not long ago, all one could expect to find in the salad-greens department of a produce stand or supermarket was iceberg, Romaine and perhaps Boston lettuce. Today there are at least a dozen choices and it seems as though more are added every season.

headline.main: Spring Salads With Some Less-Common Greens

byline.original: By Susan Herrmann Loomis: Susan Herrmann Loomis is the author of ''The Great American Seafood Cookbook'' (Workman)

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: RECENTLY, A DEAR fried came to visit from Seattle. I met her at the baggage Carousel where she stood surrounded by luggage and one crisp, square box. The label read ''perishable,'' and I knew instantly what was inside. That box contained a wealth of brilliant, fresh seafood. My friend confirmed my suspicions with a smile as wide as Broadway: ''I wanted to bring you a present, and I thought this would please you the most.

docs.lead_paragraph: ASSUMING the planning for Thanksgiving is already under way, imagine the holiday meal without pie. Well, not exactly. Consider Thanksgiving with a cobbler instead. And with good reason.

headline.main: Thanksgiving Cobblers That Are Easy as Pie but Lighter

docs.snippet: THE first thought, as fresh, newly harvested apples come into the market, is dessert. But apples, with their tart-sweet flavor, are a fine companion for savory dishes. When cooked until tender, they also soften enough to thicken a sauce.    Pork i...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE first thought, as fresh, newly harvested apples come into the market, is dessert. But apples, with their tart-sweet flavor, are a fine companion for savory dishes. When cooked until tender, they also soften enough to thicken a sauce. Pork is a classic partner for apples. But without preparing a suckling pig to serve one handsome apple, there are easier ways to combine the two. A Chinese-inspired marinade and glaze does wonders for quickly roasted pork fillets.

headline.main: Creating Savory Apple Dishes and Leaving Desserts Behind

docs.snippet: TAKE a frying chicken, cut it up, saute it, and you still have a blank canvas. Unlike a succulent roast chicken, which can stand on its own with little adornment beyond salt and pepper, a sauteed chicken requires help. It is a chameleon, ready and...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column describes how to dress up sauteed chicken dishes; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: TAKE a frying chicken, cut it up, saute it, and you still have a blank canvas. Unlike a succulent roast chicken, which can stand on its own with little adornment beyond salt and pepper, a sauteed chicken requires help. It is a chameleon, ready and able to change its personality and even its color in the pan. An exotic taste of Morocco calls for lemon and olives. China relies on ginger and snow peas, and for Mexico, some chilies and a splash of tequila do the trick. All these dishes are simple and quick to make. The chicken with lemon and olives is excellent with steamed couscous on the side. For the other two, rice is all you need.

headline.main: Adding Color to Empty Canvas of Sauteed Chicken

docs.snippet: SWEETLY luscious ripe pears have an affinity for nuts of all kinds. Walnuts, pecans and almonds can be scattered on pear desserts and salads or used in the batter of pear cakes.     Though good pears are on the market now, it is best not to buy th...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant (Food) column on dishes that combine pears and nuts; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SWEETLY luscious ripe pears have an affinity for nuts of all kinds. Walnuts, pecans and almonds can be scattered on pear desserts and salads or used in the batter of pear cakes. Though good pears are on the market now, it is best not to buy them perfectly ripe, when they are often bruised, but to plan ahead: select those that are nearly ripe but sound and allow them to mellow on the kitchen counter for a day or so. Remember that pears ripen from the inside out. When ripe they yield slightly at the stem end but are still firm at the base.

headline.main: Combining Nuts With Pears for Desserts and Salads

docs.snippet: THERE is nothing like the flavor of local apples, grown for taste not storage. They are now at the peak of their season and you can find up to 40 different kinds in farmers' markets.    Most of the apples, of course, make wonderful eating raw. But...
docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson food column on apple and caramel desserts; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing like the flavor of local apples, grown for taste not storage. They are now at the peak of their season and you can find up to 40 different kinds in farmers' markets. Most of the apples, of course, make wonderful eating raw. But when it comes to dessert, apples and caramel are an unbeatable combination. One of my favorite desserts is tarte Tatin, de rigueur on the fall menu of every French bistro, an upside-down caramelized tart made famous by the Tatin sisters who served it in their restaurant in France in the early 1900's. You can buy a very expensive pan just for this dish, but I make it in a cast iron skillet. The secret is to caramelize the sugar with the butter before the apples are put in and top them with the crust. I use a regular pastry dough for the crust, but it can also be made successfully with frozen puff pastry.

headline.main: Apple and Caramel Desserts Make for Gooey Goodness

docs.snippet: BLACK pasta, tinted with the ink of cuttlefish, is stunning to serve. (Cuttlefish have larger ink sacs than squid.) And the delicate marine flavor the ink imparts makes it especially good in summer either hot, with a slightly spicy tomato sauce, o...
docs.lead_paragraph: BLACK pasta, tinted with the ink of cuttlefish, is stunning to serve. (Cuttlefish have larger ink sacs than squid.) And the delicate marine flavor the ink imparts makes it especially good in summer either hot, with a slightly spicy tomato sauce, or tossed with artichokes and shrimp in a vinaigrette. Many purveyors of fresh pasta offer the black variety. It is also sold dried. Cuttlefish ink is sold in some specialty shops, so making the pasta from scratch is not a challenge. But the results are wildly impressive all the same.

headline.main: Wowing 'Em With Black Pasta Flavored by a Hint of the Sea
